com.faunadb.client.types

Class Value

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.faunadb.client.query.Expr
      • com.faunadb.client.types.Value
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Value.ArrayV, Value.BooleanV, Value.DateV, Value.DoubleV, Value.LongV, Value.NullV, Value.ObjectV, Value.RefV, Value.SetRefV, Value.StringV, Value.TimeV

    public abstract class Value
extends Expr
    Represents any scalar or non-scalar value in the FaunaDB query language. FaunaDB value types consist of all of the JSON value types, as well as the FaunaDB-specific types, Value.RefV and Value.SetRefV.

    Scalar values are Value.LongV, Value.StringV, Value.DoubleV, Value.BooleanV, Value.NullV, Value.RefV, and Value.SetRefV.

    Non-scalar values are Value.ObjectV and Value.ArrayV.

    This interface itself does not have any directly accessible data. It must first be coerced into a type before its data can be accessed.

    Example: Consider the Value node modeling the root of the tree: 

    
 {
   "ref": { "@ref": "some/ref" },
   "data": { "someKey": "string1", "someKey2": 123 }
 }

    The result tree can be accessed using: 

    
   Field<RefV> ref = Field.at("ref").to(Codec.REF);
   Field<String> someKey = Field.at("data", "someKey").to(Codec.STRING);
   Field<String> nonExistingKey = Field.at("non-existing-key").to(Codec.LONG);

   node.get(ref); // new RefV("some/ref")
   node.get(someKey); // "string1"
   node.getOptional(nonExistingKey) // Optional.absent()

    The interface also has helpers to transverse values without Field references: 

    
   node.at("ref").to(Codec.REF).get(); // new RefV("some/ref")
   node.at("data", "someKey").to(Codec.STRING).get() // "string1"
   node.at("non-existing-key").to(Codec.LONG).getOptional() // Optional.absent()
    See Also:
    FaunaDB Value Types, Field, Codec

      • collect

        public final <T> ImmutableList<T> collect(Field<T> field)
        Loop through this node collecting the Field passed, assuming the node is an instance of Value.ArrayV

        Example: Consider the Value node modeling the root of the tree: 

        
 {
   "data": {
     "arrayOfStrings": ["Jhon", "Bill"],
     "arrayOfObjects": [ {"name": "Jhon"}, {"name": "Bill"} ]
    }
 }

        The result tree can be accessed using: 

        
   node.get("arrayOfStrings").collect(Field.to(Codec.STRING)); // ["Jhon", "Bill"]

   Field<String> name = Field.at("name").to(Codec.STRING);
   node.get("arrayOfObjects").collect(name); // ["Jhon", "Bill"]
        Parameters:
        field - field to extract from each array value
        Returns:
        a ImmutableList with the collected Fields
        See Also:
        Field

      • at

        public final Value at(String... keys)
        Navigate through object's keys, assuming value is an instance of Value.ObjectV.
        Parameters:
        keys - path to navigate to
        Returns:
        Value under the path or Value.NullV

      • at

        public final Value at(int... indexes)
        Navigate through array's indexes, assuming value is an instance of Value.ArrayV
        Parameters:
        indexes - path to navigate to
        Returns:
        Value under the path or Value.NullV
